markdownRemark.html:
Recently, Google security blog published an article here which states:

Beginning in July 2018 with the release of Chrome 68, Chrome will mark all HTTP sites as “not secure”.

Google has been pushing for HTTPS for sometime now. A blog post in 2014 here tells us that Google’s search engine ranks HTTPS websites over unsecure HTTP websites.

While more and more websites and apps are becoming HTTPS enabled, we still develop these web apps on our local development environment over HTTP. Since web browsers behave slighlty differently when serving HTTPS and HTTP website, this can lead to few issues when we deploy to production.

One such issue is mixed content because some of the resource might be loaded using HTTP on a HTTPS site. More on mixed content here

Issues like these can be prevented by using HTTPS on development machine (localhost). Also, enabling HTTPS on the development version would allow it to be much more closer to the production version of the web app and hence would allow you to catch those bugs which would only show up after you deploy.

Overview of SSL Certificate generation process

Setup local HTTPS development environemt

PS: Although this guide is for linux and Mac OS, Windows users can run equivalent commands and achieve the same result.

STEP 1: Creating a Certificate Signing Request

Certificate Signing Request (CSR) is a message or block of encoded text sent from an applicant to a Certificate Authority (CA) in order to apply for a SSL Certificate. CSR usually contains all the information that needs to be stored in the SSL Certificate such as the organization name, common name (domain name), locality, and country along with public key of the applicant.

In short: CSR = Information + Public Key

A certificate authority (CA) will use a CSR to create your SSL certificate.

Hence, we need a public key to proceed with generation of CSR, so lets create that first.

Creating

openssl genrsa -des3 -out localdomain.secure.key 2048```

 Enter a password. I will be using "password" for the sake of demo.
 This will generate a key pair. The generated localdomain.secure.key is a password protected container which has both private and public keys (essentially a key pair)
openssl rsa -in localdomain.secure.key -out localdomain.insecure.key

4. Now we will generate a certificate sign request
create a configuration file for our local domain (localdomain.csr.cnf):
[req]
default_bits = 2048
prompt = no
default_md = sha256
distinguished_name = dn

[dn]
C=IN
ST=SomeState
L=SomeCity
O=SomeOrganization
OU=SomeUnit
emailAddress=test@test.com
CN = localhost

openssl req -new -sha256 -nodes -out localdomain.csr -key localdomain.insecure.key -config localdomain.csr.cnf


### Step 1: We need a Root SSL Certificate

We will be creating 
FIRST STEP: CREATE A SELF SIGNED ROOT SSL Certificate (CA) that will issue our certificates.

1.
Whether you are getting a certificate from a CA or generating your own self-signed certificate, the first step is to generate a key. 
openssl genrsa -des3 -out rootca.secure.key 2048 - generate a key with pass (password:password)

2. Now lets generate a insecure key
openssl rsa -in rootca.secure.key -out rootca.insecure.key

We will use rootca.insecure.key to generate certificates. But you can also use rootca.secure.key instead and enter the passwords when prompted.
Issue with using unsecure key is that if you accidentally expose the key all your certifiactes and services will also be vulnerable.
But since we are using it for development purpose at this time. Lets go ahead and use unsecure keys.

3. Now lets generate the root SSL certificate using our ca key.
openssl req -new -x509 -nodes -key rootca.insecure.key -sha256 -out cacert.pem -days 3650
Enter data that is asked. You can fill dummy values also for now


SECOND STEP: CREATE A CERTIFICATE SIGNING REQUEST
4. Now lets generate a new key for csr and domain certificate issuing
openssl genrsa -des3 -out localdomain.secure.key 2048 - generate a key with pass (password:password)
openssl rsa -in localdomain.secure.key -out localdomain.insecure.key

4. Now we will generate a certificate sign request
create a configuration file for our local domain (localdomain.csr.cnf):
[req]
default_bits = 2048
prompt = no
default_md = sha256
distinguished_name = dn

[dn]
C=IN
ST=SomeState
L=SomeCity
O=SomeOrganization
OU=SomeUnit
emailAddress=test@test.com
CN = localhost

openssl req -new -sha256 -nodes -out localdomain.csr -key localdomain.insecure.key -config localdomain.csr.cnf


LAST STEP: CREATE THE DOMAIN CERTIFICATE
5. Now use the localdomain.csr (certificate signing request) and our CA certificate to generate the localdomain certificate.
We need another configuration file for local domain:
lets name it localdomain.v3.ext

authorityKeyIdentifier=keyid,issuer
basicConstraints=CA:FALSE
keyUsage = digitalSignature, nonRepudiation, keyEncipherment, dataEncipherment
subjectAltName = @alt_names

[alt_names]
DNS.1 = localhost


Now run the command
openssl x509 -req -in localdomain.csr -CA cacert.pem -CAkey rootca.insecure.key -CAcreateserial -out localdomain.crt -days 500 -sha256 -extfile localdomain.v3.ext

This will generate a domain certificate from our ca (localdomain.crt)

Important files now to keep for next step are:
-your ca/root ssl certificate: cacert.pem
-your domain certificate: localdomain.crt
-your domain key: localdomain.insecure.key


IMPORTING TO BROWSERS
---------------------

We need both localdomain.insecure.key and localdomain.crt to import the crt to browsers.
Hence, We will combine them to generate a pfx file. Which is basically a container containing both certificate and the key.
This will help us import it into browsers smoothly.
So to do that
openssl pkcs12 -export -out localdomain.pfx -inkey localdomain.insecure.key -in localdomain.crt


// IMPORT TO CHROME

ONE: Type in url bar of chrome and press enter. 
chrome://settings/certificates

TWO: Now go to the tab "Authorities" 
We will import our CA (cacert.pem) into this.
Click on import 
Check the Trust this certificate for identifying websites checkbox and press OK. 
(If you scroll through the CA list you should see our CA at org-Testing or whatever you entered while generating it)

THREE: Import the domain certificates
Now go to "Your Certifiactes Tab"
Click on import 
And choose localdomain.pfx file.
If it asks for password enter the export password you used while creating the pfx



//IMPORT TO FIREFOX
6.

ONE: Type in url bar of firefox and press enter. 
about:preferences#privacy
Now scroll down to Certifiactes(under security)
and click on "View Certifiactes"

TWO: Now go to the tab "Authorities" 
We will import our CA (cacert.pem) into this.
Click on import 
Check the "Trust this CA  to identifying websites" checkbox and press OK. 
(If you scroll through the CA list you should see our CA at org-Testing or whatever you entered while generating it)

THREE: Import the domain certificates
Now go to "Your Certifiactes Tab"
Click on import 
And choose localdomain.pfx file.
If it asks for password enter the export password you used while creating the pfx


// RUNNING A DEV SERVER (http-server npm module)
// -----------------------------------------
mkdir project
cd project
npm install -g http-server
echo "Hello World" > index.html
http-server -a localhost --ssl --cert <path to>/localdomain.crt --key <path to>/localdomain.insecure.key

This runs the site in ssl mode in dev server.

Now open up https://localhost:8080 and you should see it showing https in green with secure tag on it.


// Using the certificates in a NodeJS backend locally
//----------------------------------------------------
index.js
==========
const https = require("https"); 
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');

const port = 3000;

const certOptions = {
  key: fs.readFileSync(path.resolve('../localdomain.insecure.key')),
  cert: fs.readFileSync(path.resolve('../localdomain.crt'))
};
  
https.createServer(certOptions, (reqst, resp) => { 
    resp.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'text/plain'}); 
    resp.end('Hello World Node!'); 
}).listen(port); 

console.log('Load https://localhost:' + port);


After this run node index.js and server should be running at
https://localhost:3000


Open up https://localhost:3000 and you should https working on local


Keep in mind use these certificates only for development.
These wont work in production as the certificate authority will not be trusted in your users browsers.
For production. generate a csr and then send it you CA and CA will generate a domain certificate for you.
